criticalSuccess: This is the moment where skill defeats raw size. You move with the precision of a master wrestler, reading the larger foe's balance and mass. You dart in low, under their reach, and your hands find the perfect leverage point - a joint, a limb, a position where physics bends to your will. With explosive technique, you twist and pull, using their own weight as the weapon. They try to resist, but you've positioned yourself perfectly. Their size becomes irrelevant, even disadvantageous. You wrench them into a lock that's simultaneously elegant and devastating. They can't move. They can barely breathe. And they're learning the hard lesson that in wrestling, technique trumps size every time. You've just grappled a giant!

Like David felling Goliath, you demonstrate the ultimate triumph of skill over size. You don't try to match their strength - that would be foolish. Instead, you use their mass against them. Your hands find weak points, joints that bend regardless of how big the creature is. You apply leverage at precise angles, using physics itself as your ally. With perfect positioning and expert technique, you force the larger foe into a submission hold. Their struggles only tighten your control - every movement you make is calculated to maximize mechanical advantage. They're bigger, stronger, more massive. But you're better. And your wrestling prowess has rendered their size advantage completely meaningless!
success: You employ solid wrestling technique against the size disadvantage. Moving with careful precision, you find leverage points that let you control the larger foe. It's not easy - their mass is a constant challenge - but your skill is enough to secure a restraining hold.

Your hands work with practiced efficiency, seeking and finding the angles that let technique overcome size. You manage to grapple the larger opponent through clever positioning and proper leverage application. The hold is functional, if not perfect.

Your technical approach is flawless in theory, but reality proves unkind. The larger foe's sheer size creates challenges your skill can't quite overcome. You can't find the right leverage, can't manipulate their mass effectively. Your grapple attempt fails despite your expertise.
criticalFailure: You move in with confidence, certain your wrestling technique can overcome the size disadvantage. You're wrong. Catastrophically wrong. Your attempt to find leverage is met with overwhelming mass. They don't just resist - they overpower you completely. Your clever positioning becomes awkward vulnerability. Your technical precision becomes clumsy failure. You're not just failing to grapple them - you're being dominated by them. Their size advantage, which you thought to overcome with skill, instead crushes your technique entirely. You're left exposed, off-balance, and thoroughly defeated!

Your wrestling expertise betrays you in the worst possible way. You commit to a leverage-based hold that should work, that would work against a same-sized opponent. But against this larger foe, it's a disaster. Their mass overwhelms your positioning. Their bulk defeats your technique. Not only do you fail to secure a hold, but your attempt leaves you in a terrible position - off-balance, exposed, completely at their mercy. The size disadvantage has won decisively!
